page.title: Questions - Interrogative Phrases in Content Questions
page.introduction: Content questions differ from Yes/No questions in that they contain an interrogative word or phrase, known as wh-phrases in English because they almost all begin with wh (who(m), what, why, where, when, how, which, whose).

form.prompt: Key a list of the interrogative words in your language, with each word followed by a "Tab" and then its English gloss in single quotes, then "Enter" here:
form.introduction: Of the examples of interrogative words above, most simply stand alone as pronouns or adverbs, but how can either be a manner adverb by itself or a degree word modifying an adjective, as in how big or a degree word modifying a quantifier, as in how many children; what can either be a pronoun by itself or a demonstrative modifying a noun, as in what books; which never stands alone but always modifies a noun as a demonstrative, as in which boy; and whose can be either a stand alone possessive pronoun, or it can fill the possessor position in a nominal phrase, as in whose toys.
form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark all of the interrogative words with the feature wh.
In addition, make sure that your word meaning 'which' either already has the category Dem or add the makeDem to the entry. In addition, since your language does not have any demonstratives, make sure that your word meaning 'which' either already has the category Art or add the feature makeArt to the entry. In addition, since your language does not have any demonstratives or articles, if you have a word meaning 'which', it will have to be treated as a possessor. As such, it simply acts as a pronoun like the majority of the interrogative words, and the category mapping will be handled on the testing page at the end of this section. Add the case feature genitive to the entry to restrict its appearance to possessor position.
absolutive to the entry to restrict the positions where it may appear.
ergative to the entry to restrict the positions where it may appear.
The word meaning 'why' needs to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you are mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature reason.
The word meaning 'where' needs to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you are mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature locative.
The word meaning 'how' needs to have two entries, one with the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you are mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner and another entry which can have any appropriate morphological cateogry but has the features Deg modifies_Adj modifies_Q. The word meaning 'how' needs to have two entries, one with the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you are mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner and another entry which can have any appropriate morphological cateogry but has the features Deg modifies_Q. The word meaning 'how' needs to have two entries, one with the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you are mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner and another entry which can have any appropriate morphological category but has the features Deg modifies_Adj. Since your language does not have stand alone degree words that modify quantifiers, you may have another interrogative word meaning 'how many' and/or 'how much'. These words/phrases act like quantifiers, so the entry needs to have the features Q wh. The word meaning 'how' needs to have the category Adv (or your morphological category for adverbs that you are mapped to Adv in
Adverbs and AdvP) and the feature manner. Since your language does not have stand alone degree words that modify quantifiers, you may have another interrogative word meaning 'how many' and/or 'how much'. These words/phrases act like quantifiers, so the entry needs to have the features Q wh.
The word meaning 'what' also needs two entries if it can modify a noun as in English. This entry which allows it to modify a noun needs to have the category Dem or add the makeDem to the entry.
The normal pronoun use of the word meaning 'what' and the remainder of the interrogative words above need to be mapped to the category Pron. This will be handled on the testing page at the end of this section.
The word meaning 'what' also needs two entries if it can modify a noun as in English. Since your language does not have any demonstratives, this entry which allows it to modify a noun needs to have the category Art or add the feature makeArt to the entry.
The normal pronoun use of the word meaning 'what' and the remainder of the interrogative words above need to be mapped to the category Pron. This will be handled on the testing page at the end of this section.
Since your language does not have any demonstratives or articles, the word meaning 'what' only needs one entry, since it simply acts as a pronoun like the majority of the interrogative words, and the category mapping to the category Pron will be handled on the testing page at the end of this section. Do not add any case features to the entry, so it will be allowed in possessor position as well as taking the place of a full nominal phrase.
The word meaning 'whose' needs to have two entries, both with the category which will be mapped to the category Pron at the end of the section (and both with the feature wh). One entry needs the feature possessive for the stand alone case and the other entry needs the case feature genitive to restrict its appearance to possessor position.
absolutive to restrict the positions where it may appear.
ergative to restrict the positions where it may appear.

radioGroup.prompt: Your language allows demonstratives on either side of the noun. Where do the words meaning 'which' and 'what' occur?
radioGroup.radio: Always before the noun, even if another determiner occurs after the noun
Always after the noun, even if another determiner occurs before the noun
On either side, but when there is a demonstrative on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be)

radioGroup.prompt: Your language allows articles on either side of the noun. Where do the words meaning 'which' and 'what' occur?
radioGroup.radio: Always before the noun, even if another article occurs after the noun
Always after the noun, even if another article occurs before the noun
On either side, but when there is an article on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be)

radioGroup.prompt: Your language allows degree words on either side of the adjective. Where does the word meaning 'how' (or any other interrogative words which can modify adjectives) occur?
radioGroup.radio: Always before the adjective, even if another degree word occurs after the adjective
Always after the adjective, even if another degree word occurs before the adjective
On either side, but when there is a degree word on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be)

radioGroup.prompt: Your language allows degree words on either side of the quantifier. Where does the word meaning 'how' (or any other interrogative words which can modify quantifiers) occur?
radioGroup.radio: Always before the quantifier, even if another degree word occurs after the quantifier
Always after the quantifier, even if another degree word occurs before the quantifier
On either side, but when there is a degree word on each side at the same time, they must agree in features (e.g. both be interrogative words or both not be)
